speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about the rash? How long have you had it, and when did it first appear?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about 5 months ago, and I remember it was during a particularly busy semester in college when I was working on a design project late at night. I think I might have spilled some ink on my skin, but it didn't really bother me at first."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so the rash started about 2 weeks ago, and it's been getting progressively worse. Can you tell me more about the rash itself - is it itchy, red, scaly, or does it have any other characteristics that might be helpful to know?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been really itchy, and it feels a bit like sandpaper on my skin. The color's not really changed much, it's mostly stayed the same - just a bit darker than my normal skin tone. And when I scratch it, it sometimes bleeds a little bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the location of the rash exactly, are they limited to just the upper extremities, or are there any other areas affected as well?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's actually limited to both of my upper extremities - my arms, to be precise. I have one arm that's almost entirely affected, and the other arm is about 75% affected. It's just these two areas, though, and that's the only place I've noticed any real changes."

speaker: Doctor
text:

Can you also describe the intensity of the itching - is it mild, moderate, or severe?



Please go ahead and respond to the patient.

text:

I've been trying to keep my skin moisturized, but I guess that's not doing much to help right now."

"As for triggers, I've been working on this design project non-stop, so I've been sitting at my desk for hours every day. I've also noticed that the itching gets worse when I'm feeling anxious or stressed, which is weird because I thought that would help me relax."

"The itching is pretty intense, to be honest.
